>>245203271
I usually love it. The title in my opinion is best when it has intimate connection to what the series is about, perhaps even spoiling parts of it in a subtle way. A title drop, if done well, reinforces this connection, confirms that the title has a reason for being what it is.
Roadside Picnic seems like a dissonant title until you get the title drop and understand that's it's actually intimately connected to the story themes. Dr Stone immediately establishes the series setting (modern science (Dr) in prehistoric world (Stone)), and then just keeps getting new meanings in the story. Dungeon Meshi seems like a straightforward title and never quite gets a title drop, but with time it too turns out to not be quite so straightforward.
A good title is poetic, as is a good title drop. You can absolutely fuck it up and not every title can inherently be dropped in that way, but when it's done well, it's beautiful, like a good rhyme.

Hijinks ensue as the two strike up a deal to give each other their darkest, most private secrets in order to equip the other with the weapons they need to conquer the heart of their other selves.
